timeline.message: Add TenantInfo classes and wire them in CloudTenant and serialization code
Add unit tests and fix accordingly
Back and forth on which cursor to work with in tenantinfo serialization
Remove rest api parser - for another pr

timeline.bodyText: Should be named simply EMPTY, same goes for the other classes.
timeline.author: mpolden

replies.bodyText: I wasn't aware of that. Is there a naming convention document that I have missed?
replies.author: smorgrav

replies.bodyText: In general the Java convention is UPPERCASE for constants. In this module we typically name such constants either EMPTY/NONE or empty/none.
replies.author: mpolden

timeline.bodyText: This should just call the constructor directly as the immutable builder methods will create a new object per field.
timeline.author: mpolden

replies.bodyText: Not sure I understand - what is the difference?
replies.author: smorgrav

replies.bodyText: The difference is the number of objects you create. In the current state it's multiplied by the number of fields in TenantInfo (since each withXXX creates a new object), this is then multiplied by the number of tenants you're deserializing.
replies.author: mpolden

replies.bodyText: Ah - an optimisation. Using builder methods adds some benefits that I think outweigh that - one is that the order of the constructor when using strings are prone to mistakes (and this eliminates that).
replies.author: smorgrav

timeline.author: mpolden
mpolden

timeline.bodyText: If this implements equals/hashCode you can simply return this.equals(EMPTY). Same for the other classes. This will also simplify serialization testing.
timeline.author: mpolden

replies.bodyText:
Good catch!
Could you give a hint to what part of testing could be simplified due to this?
replies.author: smorgrav

replies.bodyText: If you add a fully populated TenantInfo to @Test public void cloud_tenant() you can do do assertEquals(tenant.tenantInfo(), serialized.tenantInfo()) to test that serialization works as expected in both directions.
replies.author: mpolden

replies.bodyText: Ah you where referring to if it implemented equals/hashCode - not how to implement the isEmpty method?I think that is exactly what is done right?
replies.author: smorgrav

replies.bodyText: Yes, never mind! You should still be able to simplify isEmpty though, by just comparing with empty.
replies.author: mpolden

timeline.bodyText: Should set a non-empty TenantInfo here, and assert the re-serialized value below to ensure that serialization is correct.
timeline.author: mpolden

replies.bodyText: I guess. The non empty case is covered below (albeit not in the context of a CloudTenant) - the normal case is that it is empty. I can create another test.
replies.author: smorgrav

replies.bodyText: Right, I didn't notice the other tests.
replies.author: mpolden

replies.bodyText: Fixed. Added one extra test there to cover that the info field is set correctly in the tenant object.
replies.author: smorgrav

timeline.author: mpolden

+import java.util.Objects;

+ * This info is used to capture generic support information and invoiced billing information.
+ *
+ * All fields are non null but strings can be empty
+ */

@@ -0,0 +1,75 @@
+package com.yahoo.vespa.hosted.controller.tenant;
+
+import java.util.Objects;
+
+/**
+ * Address formats are quite diverse across the world both in therms of what fields are used, named and
+ * the order of them.
+ *
+ * To be generic a little future proof the address fields here are a mix of free text (address lines) and fixed fields.
+ * The address lines can be street address, P.O box, c/o name, apartment, suite, unit, building floor etc etc.
+ *
+ * All fields are mandatory but can be an empty string (ie. not null)
+ */
+public class TenantInfoAddress {

timeline.message: Rename empty singletons, simplify isEmpty and add author tag
Add one unit test of the cloud tenant serialization with non empty info
